description.narrative:
More than 15,000 children are homeless in San Diego. Many do not know where their next meal will come from. For these vulnerable children, poor nutrition can lead to vitamin and mineral deficiencies, with dire consequences for growth and development; success in school; and overall well being.
In collaboration with the San Diego Unified School District and The Jacobs and Cushman San Diego Food Bank, IRT fills this gap by providing weekly nutrition support to homeless school children at Fay Elementary School and Linda Vista Elementary. Since 2011, IRT volunteers have supported hundreds of school children, providing them with backpacks containing a variety of food, including cereal, evaporated milk, canned fruit, vegetables, and beans; peanut butter and jelly; crackers, rice, pasta, soup, and other snacks.
One of IRT’s goals is to teach students how to live a healthy lifestyle, including eating a balanced diet, drinking water, getting enough sleep and exercising every day. We incorporate these principles into weekly puzzles and worksheets that are placed inside each student's backpack and are both fun to do, and educational. Once a student completes four worksheets, they receive a prize delivered in their backpack: pencils, pens, crayons, markers, and toys such as yo-yo's, glow-in-the-dark light sticks, playing cards, balls and Frisbees.
